subject: Re: Unicode proposal again.
msgSnippet: Does a Unicode proposal designate which characters are letters?  After reading through the discussion of the proposal I wondered about using Quikscript in
messageBody:
Does a Unicode proposal designate which characters are letters? After
reading through the discussion of the proposal I wondered about using
Quikscript in identifiers in programming languages.

Java allows letters from various languages and a few other characters
as identifiers in a program. The library also has routines that
determine if a character is a letter. I looked at the Java Language
Specification which makes reference to isJavaIdentifierStart and
isJavaIdentifierPart. These seem to indicate that it depends on
whether the Unicode character designates a letter in some language.
Is there something in the proposal that designates characters as
letters? Is the naming dot a letter or punctuation?

The Python library refers to "the Unicode Character Database which
defines character properties for all Unicode characters" as the source
for the Python library routines to return information about the
characters. Does any of this come from the proposal?

Jerome

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, amd64_hacker <amd64_hacker@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
> As promised (and thanks to some free time over the bank holiday) I've
> been looking at the Unicode Consortium's process for submitting new
scripts.
>
> I think that we've more or less answered all the questions that we need
> for the proposal a while back but just to be certain this is what I
> think we came up with:
> The 4 letter (iso-15924) script code we want is 'quik'.
> The letter glyphs should be encoded in numerical order followed by the
> glyphs for Loch, Llan, Examine, Excite and the angled parenthesis.
>
> I'm not too certain about the naming dot.
> I did argue against reusing the middle dot but Annex F of the Principles
> and Procedure document (very boring,
> http://www.dkuug.dk/JTC1/SC2/WG2/docs/n3102.pdf) can be read both in
> favour of encoding and reusing.
>
> I notice that the Shavian mapping doesn't have a dot, does anybody know
> which character they use instead?
> Should we have our own dot or reuse the middle dot?
> Perhaps should put in the naming dot and leave it up to the Unicode guys
> to suggest the middle dot if they think it's worth while?
>
> Anyway if we sort that out and everyone's okay with it I'd be happy to
> prepare and submit the proposal.
>
